questiontext.text:
A group of researchers looks at the effect of gender and whether or not a smiley-face is applied on accounts and average tip percentage. The researchers suggest including the following sentence in the research paper:

The study finds that there are no significant differences in average tip percentages between accounts with a smiley face and those without a smiley face, F = 2, p = .135.

Are the researchers correct to report this? Why or why not?

answer.text: Yes, because the p-value is greater than 0.05 and then no difference is present and it is not important to look further
Yes, because the interaction effect results are significant and so there are no differences between the waiters and waitresses

No, because the F value is equal to 2, and that is almost equal to 1 and then we cannot draw reliable conclusions about whether or not there are differences between the accounts with and the accounts without smiley-face

No, because she has to look at the interaction effect first, and it turns out that there are differences between the accounts with a smiley-face and those without, but only within the two gender groups
